title: 108_s622
content: The "Family Opportunity Act of 2004" or the "Dylan Lee James Act" makes amendments to the Social Security Act. The table of contents for this Act is provided. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2004" makes amendments to the Social Security Act, including provisions for families of disabled children to purchase Medicaid coverage for them. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2004" allows families of disabled children to purchase Medicaid coverage for them, specifically for disabled children under 18 years of age. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2004" allows families to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 18 years of age who would be considered disabled but have income exceeding SSI requirements. Family income must not exceed 250 percent of the poverty line set by the State. Family income must not exceed 250 percent of the poverty line set by the State. State funds are provided for individuals below the poverty line, with no Federal financial participation for medical assistance. Employer-sponsored family coverage under a group health plan must be applied for and enrolled in by parents of eligible individuals. The Family Opportunity Act of 2004 allows parents to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 18 with income exceeding SSI requirements. Employer-sponsored family coverage must be applied for and enrolled in by parents of eligible individuals. Premiums for such coverage are required if the parent is eligible and the employer contributes at least 50% of the total cost. The coverage obtained should be treated as a third party liability. The Family Opportunity Act of 2004 allows parents to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 18 with income exceeding SSI requirements. States have the option to provide payment for family coverage premiums for eligible parents. Additionally, states can impose income-related premiums on families of disabled children receiving medical assistance. The Family Opportunity Act of 2004 allows parents to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 18 with income exceeding SSI requirements. States can impose income-related premiums on families of disabled children receiving medical assistance, based on a sliding scale tied to family income. Premium requirements must not exceed 7.5 percent of the family's income for disabled children with family income below 250 percent of the poverty line. States cannot require prepayment of premiums or terminate eligibility for failure to pay. The amendment allows states to terminate Medicaid coverage for disabled children if premium payment is not made for at least 60 days. The state can waive the premium in cases of undue hardship. Additionally, the amendment clarifies that the enhanced FMAP cannot be applied to expenditures for disabled children under a specific section of the Social Security Act. The amendments made by this section apply to medical assistance for items and services provided on or after October 1, 2006. SEC. 3. Treatment of inpatient psychiatric hospital services for individuals under age 21 in home or community-based services waivers. Section 1915(c) (42 U.S.C. 1396n(c)) is amended to include coverage for inpatient psychiatric hospital services for individuals under age 21 in home or community-based services waivers. In paragraph (2)(C), the amendment includes coverage for inpatient psychiatric hospital services for individuals under age 21 in home or community-based services waivers. This expands the services available to individuals in need of mental health care. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply with respect to medical assistance provided on or after October 1, 2006. SEC. 4. DEVELOPMENT AND SUPPORT OF FAMILY-TO-FAMILY HEALTH INFORMATION CENTERS. Section 501 (42 U.S.C. 701) is amended to provide funding for special projects supporting family-to-family health information centers. $3,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2006, $4,000,000 for fiscal year 2007, and $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2008. Additionally, $5,000,000 is authorized for each of fiscal years 2009 and 2010. The family-to-family health information centers receive additional funding and remain available until expended. These centers assist families of children with disabilities in making informed health care choices, provide information on resources available, and identify successful health delivery models. The family-to-family health information centers aim to identify successful health delivery models for children with disabilities, collaborate with health care providers, provide training and guidance, conduct outreach activities, and be staffed by families with expertise in health care systems. The family-to-family health information centers will be developed in at least 25 states in fiscal year 2006, 40 states in fiscal year 2007, and all states in fiscal year 2008. The provisions of this title apply to funds available to the Secretary for these centers. The term 'State' refers to all 50 states and the District of Columbia. SEC. 5. RESTORATION OF MEDICAID ELIGIBILITY FOR CERTAIN SSI BENEFICIARIES. Amends Section 1902(a)(10)(A)(i)(II) to include individuals under 21 years of age eligible for supplemental security income benefits. Effective from January 1, 2006, for medical assistance. Passed the Senate on May 6, 2004. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
